results.title: Like rings on water
results.brief_description: Discusses the problems of traffic congestion in large cities, and advocates a theory of town planning with effective decentralisation. Suggests a complex of small centres around a larger focal point. Although people naturally gravitate to cities most of their activities could be just as well performed in a more rural setting which could also allow for more freedom, individualism and fresh air.

results.title: Like other people
results.creator_credit: Irving Teitelbaum, Kestrel Films (Australia) and Paul Morrison
results.brief_description: This film depicts many aspects of the lives of handicapped adults living in a residential home run by the Spastic Society. It centres on the lives of Willie and Margaret, and shows their desire for as normal a life as possible. Highlights the need to carefully consider how society treats disabled people. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Like ordinary children
results.brief_description: Focuses on a school in Kent which is for handicapped children. This film is seen through the eyes of the handicapped children themselves, in particular, those with spinal injuries. Also describes the opinions of the older children from the senior school towards the handicapped children. Colorful and informative.

results.title: Like nowhere else
results.brief_description: Like nowhere else graphically summarises some of the changes that have taken place in the Australian landscape since European settlement. We see environmental destruction resulting from the “develop at any cost” mentality that has shaped human relationships with the environment in this country for so long. We also see hope for the future in the growing community concern and the response of governments and industry. Narrated by Robyn Williams with music by Gondwanaland.

results.title: Like mother...like daughter
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling, Christine Lamb and ACMI
results.brief_description: Christine Lamb is constantly told how much she’s like her mother. It is through looking back on her life and all the things her mother taught her, that Lamb learns how similar they really are.

results.title: Like it is. Eps 1-8
results.brief_description: Like It Is is an ABC health series for middle-secondary students, consisting of eight twenty minute episodes which focus on life issues of concern to young people, and presents skills and strategies to help deal with them. The programs use interviews and real life situations to examine how issues of group identity, self-esteem, career goals, friendship, sexual relationships, mental stress, change, loss, and risk taking are experienced by young Australians. The music video clip production style is designed to engage young people, and the series was produced with the assistance of curriculum officers, mental health specialists and target audience focus groups. Episode 1 “Belonging”: explores what it’s like to be excluded and the benefits of feeling connected. Strategies such as optimistic self-talk, communication skills, and acceptance, are presented as ways to connect with others and to make other people feel included. Episode 2 “Feeling Good”: deals with self esteem, including the idea that our self esteem can change. Strategies to keep our self esteem high such as optimistic self-talk, identifying personal strengths and help-seeking are discussed. Episode 3 “Where am I going?”: looks at goal setting and decision-making. It focuses on career goals, discusses the advantages of developing transferable skills and encourages the pursuit of rich tasks. Episode 4 “Friends”: highlights the importance of friendship, and focuses on the importance of liking yourself first. Skills such as communication, optimistic self-talk and decision-making are presented as strategies for managing friendships. Episode 5 “More Than Friends”: discusses how to recognise and contribute to a positive relationship and looks at ideas including trust when considering a sexual relationship. Episode 6 “Managing stress”: looks at some positive and challenging aspects of stress in our lives and investigates a range of strategies including optimistic self-talk, humour, exercise and help-seeking as ways to manage stress. Episode 7 “Managing Change”: explores the idea that change is part of life, discussing both positive change and the more challenging aspects of change, such as loss and grief. Strategies presented to help manage change include goal setting, communication, help-seeking, and decision-making. Episode 8 “Taking risks”: examines risk-taking as a natural part of growing up which can present positive challenges and test developing coping skills. Risk-assessment, decision-making and help-seeking strategies are discussed as ways to reduce risk factors and minimise harm.

results.title: Like it is
results.creator_credit: Chris Begley, George Nevile, John Brawley and Tony D'Aquino
results.brief_description: When an elderly women is forced to have her beloved budgie put down, a vet’s assistant is disturbed by his employer’s unscrupulous practices. A touching short film about human compassion. Cast includes Dylan Lewis, Frank Gallacher and Dawn Klingberg.

results.title: Like it is
results.creator_credit: Tracey Gardiner, Channel Four Films and Paul Oremland
results.brief_description: This low-budget romantic drama marks Paul Oremland’s directorial debut. Craig is a 21 year old boxer from Blackpool, making cash from illegal bare-knuckle fights. A chance meeting outside a club leads him to a brief sexual encounter with Matt, a self-assured disc-jockey from London. He flees the escalating violence of Blackpool and turns up on Matt’s doorstep where he is introduced to the freedom of Soho, an openly gay world he never imagined existed. As the pair become more involved the illusions on which their relationship is built begins to crumble, not helped by Matt’s scheming gay boss (Roger Daltrey) and possessive flatmate, who seek to break them up. Cast includes Steve Bell, Ian Rose and Dani Behr.

results.title: Like drowning
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television, Robert Stephenson, Ann Shenfield, Paul Fletcher and Cath Murphy
results.brief_description: A moving animated tale about a young family who try to come to terms with the sudden death of one of the children through drowning. The family struggles to cope and adopt drastic changes in their lifestyle in order to come to terms with the ordeal.
